title: Error: 'import' and 'export' may appear only with 'sourceType: module', When running sls deploy
body:
### Are you certain it's a bug?

- [x] Yes, it looks like a bug

### Is the issue caused by a plugin?

- [X] It is not a plugin issue

### Are you using the latest v3 release?

- [X] Yes, I'm using the latest v3 release

### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched existing issues, it hasn't been reported yet

### Issue description

running a deploy throws an Error: 'import' and 'export' may appear only with 'sourceType: module'.

Trying setting "sourceType" to "module" and it didn't work.

### Service configuration (serverless.yml) content

```yaml
service: nest-serverless-lambda

plugins:
 - 'serverless-plugin-typescript'
 - serverless-plugin-optimize
 - serverless-offline
 - serverless-webpack

provider:
 name: aws
 runtime: nodejs14.x

functions:
 oa-staging-backend:
   handler: packages/backend/src/app/lambda.handler
   events:
     - http:
         method: any
         path: /{any+}
```


### Command name and used flags

sls deploy --verbose --debug "*"

@basselabbara try it without serverless-plugin-optimize
@ahmadissa I already had to do it that way and it worked so I created an issue on the plugin's issue page. So far no response so I guess I'm gonna have to move on without optimize.

If you want to use axios while using optimization, you can exclude the relevant modules from optimization.
ex:
```
custom:
  optimize:
    external:
      [
        'axios',
        'form-data',
        'combined-stream',
        'delayed-stream',
        'mime-types',

title: Serverless tries to remove unused role
body:
### Are you certain it's a bug?

- [X] Yes, it looks like a bug

### Is the issue caused by a plugin?

- [X] It is not a plugin issue

### Are you using the latest v3 release?

- [X] Yes, I'm using the latest v3 release

### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched existing issues, it hasn't been reported yet

### Issue description

I used to have IAM roles created by Serverless Framework, called `events-dev-eu-central-1-lambdaRole`. I replaced it with manually created roles `dev-event-processing-deployment-role` (for deploy) and `dev-event-processing-execution-role` (for execution):
```
  iam:
    # role assumed by account, Jenkins and CloudFormation to deploy resources
    deploymentRole: dev-event-processing-deployment-role

    # Lambda execution role
    role: dev-event-processing-execution-role
```

I expected Serverless to just use a new role and do not touch the old one - it should have no knowledge about it. However, upon deploy I get an error:
```
Error:
DELETE_FAILED: IamRoleLambdaExecution (AWS::IAM::Role)
API: iam:DeleteRolePolicy User: arn:aws:sts::590463175157:assumed-role/dev-event-processing-deployment-role/AWSCloudFormation is not authorized to perform: iam:DeleteRolePolicy on resource: role events-dev-eu-central-1-lambdaRole because no identity-based policy allows the iam:DeleteRolePolicy action
```

This can be reproduced with any toy example: create "hello world" function with autogenerated IAM role, replace with manually created one without `iam:DeleteRolePolicy`, try to update.

### Service configuration (serverless.yml) content

```yaml
N/A
```


### Command name and used flags

serverless deploy

### Command output

```shell
Deploying events to stage dev (eu-central-1)

✖ Stack events-dev failed to deploy (75s)
Environment: linux, node 18.6.0, framework 3.22.0 (local), plugin 6.2.2, SDK 4.3.2
Credentials: Local, "dev" profile
Docs:        docs.serverless.com
Support:     forum.serverless.com
Bugs:        github.com/serverless/serverless/issues

Error:
DELETE_FAILED: IamRoleLambdaExecution (AWS::IAM::Role)
API: iam:DeleteRolePolicy User: arn:aws:sts::590463175157:assumed-role/dev-event-processing-deployment-role/AWSCloudFormation is not authorized to perform: iam:DeleteRolePolicy on resource: role events-dev-eu-central-1-lambdaRole because no identity-based policy allows the iam:DeleteRolePolicy action
```


### Environment information

```shell
Framework Core: 3.22.0 (local)
Plugin: 6.2.2
SDK: 4.3.2
```
author: j-adamczyk

comments.body: @j-adamczyk by referencing _external_ role you've stated that there's no need for Serverless to create one for you, and it's the reason it was removed from the deployment stack (in result removed after deployment).

Ok, but I do not want it to be deleted. It is still used by other Serverless deployments, just not by this particular one, that's why this is a problem. Even if I have Serverless permissions, it still would not be able to delete this role, as it is in use by other services. I don't think that this is the right behavior, as this way there is no way (at least that I know of) to use Serverless for this, but rather I have to fix all of this manually.

> Ok, but I do not want it to be deleted. It is still used by other Serverless deployments, just not by this particular one, that's why this is a problem

This role should not be used by anything outside of the created stack. I think the problem here is, that you've created a dependency that should not exist, and CF stack is not aware of.
Ok, I see that now, thank you

title: Migrating from x86_64 to arm64 Graviton2 processor not updated
body:
### Are you certain it's a bug?

- [X] Yes, it looks like a bug

### Is the issue caused by a plugin?

- [X] It is not a plugin issue

### Are you using the latest version?

- [X] Yes, I'm using the latest version

### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched existing issues, it hasn't been reported yet

### Issue description

We tried to migrate our development env's lambda workload from x86_64 to arm64 Graviton2 processor using a serverless framework. serverless deployment was successful but the processor configuration was not changed. still it was using x86 processor. When I tried to change it manually on the AWS console, it was saying 
```
If the function uses a compiled language, or the function size exceeds the code editor storage limit (3 MB), you must upload a .zip file archive (or .jar file) when you change the architecture. Uploading a new .zip file package overwrites the existing code.
```
 Is there any alternative way to override this? or how to change/migrate the processor without recreating/rebuilding the code?

```
provider:
  name: aws
  runtime: nodejs12.x
  timeout: 90
  memorySize: 1024
  tracing: ture
  architecture: arm64
```

FYI: if the code is less than 3MB and if it is not a zip file, I can change the processor using `sls deploy`

### Service configuration (serverless.yml) content

```yaml
N/A
```


### Command name and used flags

N/A

### Command output

```shell
serverless --deploy --stage flux
```


### Environment information

```shell
sh-4.2# serverless --version
Framework Core: 2.18.0
Plugin: 4.4.2
SDK: 2.3.2
Components: 3.4.6
sh-4.2#
```
author: pbalajiips

comments.body:
@pbalajiips actually you're using highly outdated version (you've checked _Yes, I'm using the latest version_ but that's not true).

Please upgrade

@medikoo Thanks a lot!!!, with recent version i can update the processors arch.

title: Unable to override `service` using command option
body:
In my previous projects I was configuring the name of the service using a command option. This let my team each deploy their own stack using a unique CF stack name. This was done by setting `service: ${opt:serviceName, 'default-service-name'}`. Since version 2.32.0, when attempting this, the commands fail with the following error: `Cannot resolve serverless.yml: "service" property is not accessible (configured behind variables which cannot be resolved at this stage)`. If I switch to using an environment variable instead of a command options (`${opt:....` to ${env:....`) then it will succeed.
serverless.yml ```yaml service: ${opt:serviceName, 'hermes'} frameworkVersion: '2' variablesResolutionMode: 20210326 provider: name: aws runtime: go1.x lambdaHashingVersion: 20201221 memorySize: 512 versionFunctions: false logRetentionInDays: 14 tracing: apiGateway: true lambda: 'Active' deploymentBucket: blockPublicAccess: true name: catalog.${self:provider.region}.deploys iam: role: statements: - Effect: Allow Action: - xray:PutTraceSegments - xray:PutTelemetryRecords Resource: "*" environment: SERVICE_NAME: ${self:service} plugins: - serverless-go-plugin functions: hello: handler: function/hello/main.go events: - httpApi: path: /hello method: get ```
serverless deploy --serviceName dev1-hermes output ``` Serverless Error ---------------------------------------- Cannot resolve serverless.yml: "service" property is not accessible (configured behind variables which cannot be resolved at this stage) Get Support -------------------------------------------- Docs: docs.serverless.com Bugs: github.com/serverless/serverless/issues Issues: forum.serverless.com Your Environment Information --------------------------- Operating System: darwin Node Version: 14.15.3 Framework Version: 2.44.0 Plugin Version: 5.2.0 SDK Version: 4.2.3 Components Version: 3.11.0 ```

author: SkippyZA

comments.body:
@SkippyZA In latest versions to introduce solid CLI params validation, we've stopped supporting free form CLI params injection, and new variables resolver (to which you've completely switched via `variablesResolutionMode: 20210326`) doesn't recognize them in variables resolution)

Insteead please rely on environment variables as e.g.:

```
SERVICE_NAME=dev1-hermes sls deploy output
```

```serverless.yml
service: ${env:SERVICE_NAME, 'hermes'}
...
```
That is unfortunate. Thanks for the info 👍

title: Unable to configure provisioned concurrency 0
body:
<!--
Q1: Describe the problem (use case) that needs to be solved:
-->

When using `configValidationMode: error` and provisioned concurrency is set to 0 for some function, an error is thrown requiring:
```
Configuration error at 'functions.authorizer.provisionedConcurrency': should be >= 1
```

### Use case description

This would be useful in cases where provisioned concurrency is only desired for certain stage deployments.  It allows the provisioned concurrency configuration to be conditional.

<!--
Q2: Propose a solution (e.g. provide configuration example)
-->

### Proposed solution

Allow provisioned concurrency 0 - it currently works without `configValidationMode: error`, which is useful in cases where provisioned currency is only desired for certain stage deployments.  It allows the provisioned concurrency configuration to be conditional.

```
functions:
  authorizer:
    handler: handler
    provisionedConcurrency: ${self:custom.config.authorizer-provisioned-concurrency}
```
author: jackmuskopf

comments.body: @jackmuskopf if you don't want to setup `provisionedConcurrency` but for some technical reason need to keep property in configuration, simply set it to `null`

@medikoo Using `null` works with `configValidationMode: error` but leads me to a different concern: using `null` fails with

```
  Cannot resolve serverless.yml: Variables resolution errored with:
    - Cannot resolve variable at "functions.authorizer.provisionedConcurrency": Value not found at "self" 
source
```

when using `variablesResolutionMode: 20210326`, which like `configValidationMode: error` looks like it will become default in the next major release.  Maybe I can use `configValidationMode: warn` after the next major release.
Excellent! Thank you!

title: Remove trailing & leading quotes from env refs
body:
## What did you implement:
This PR removes straling and leading `"` or `'` from env variables. This was not a problem for function cloud formation template definition but was so for resources.

If you had en env like so `export TEST_ENV="abcdefg?a"` the quotes would be escaped in the resource CF template json as `Value: "\"abcdefg?a\""`.

## How did you implement it:

`getValueFromEnv` now calls `getValueFromString` if the value is a string

## How can we verify it:

Try use an env value surrounded by quotes and use that somewhere in your resources, ie:
```yaml
resources:
  Resources:
    DBCluster:
      Type: "AWS::DocDB::DBCluster"
      DeletionPolicy: Delete
      Properties:
        DBClusterIdentifier: ${self:custom.dbClusterName}
        MasterUsername: rvadmin
        MasterUserPassword: ${env:DB_PASSWORD}
```
## Todos:

_**Note: Run `npm run test-ci` to run all validation checks on proposed changes**_

- [X] Write tests and confirm existing functionality is not broken.  
       **Validate via `npm test`**
- [X] Write documentation
- [X] Ensure there are no lint errors.  
       **Validate via `npm run lint-updated`**  
       _Note: Some reported issues can be automatically fixed by running `npm run lint:fix`_
- [X] Ensure introduced changes match Prettier formatting.  
       **Validate via `npm run prettier-check-updated`**  
       _Note: All reported issues can be automatically fixed by running `npm run prettify-updated`_
- [X] Make sure code coverage hasn't dropped
- [X] Provide verification config / commands / resources
- [X] Enable "Allow edits from maintainers" for this PR
- [X] Update the messages below

**_Is this ready for review?:_** YES  
**_Is it a breaking change?:_** NO
author: richarddd

comments.body:
> > If you had en env like so export TEST_ENV="abcdefg?a" the quotes would be escaped in the resource CF template json as Value: ""abcdefg?a"".
> 
> In this case `TEST_ENV` will originally resolve to `abcdefg?a` (no quotes, and there's nothing to strip).
> To have value quoted it'll have to be exported as `export TEST_ENV="\"abcdefg?a\""`.
> 
> Generally if someone put quotes into env var values, it's either intentional, or some error in env variables setup.
> 
> I have an impression that with that we're interfering too far, and may accidentally trim values which were not meant to be stripped
> 
> Can you share more light on your use case?

Well that really depends on how you see it. Imaging you want a string or some other value with special characters as an env variable. You would enclose it in quotes. For instance:
```bash
export VARIABLE="AAA?BBB&CC_C"
echo $VARIABLE
````
Which is far more common than escaping all the values (for readability):
```bash
export VARIABLE=AAA?BBB\&CC\_C
echo $VARIABLE
```
This PR will only strip "surrounding" quotes.

> This PR will only strip "surrounding" quotes.

In cases you mention, there seem no surrounding quotes to strip

```bash
$ export VARIABLE="AAA?BBB&CC_C"
$ echo $VARIABLE
AAA?BBB&CC_C
```

> > This PR will only strip "surrounding" quotes.
> 
> In cases you mention, there are no surrounding quotes to strip
> 
> ```shell
> $ export VARIABLE="AAA?BBB&CC_C"
> $ echo $VARIABLE
> AAA?BBB&CC_C
> ```

Try adding that to your serverless.yml and you'll get a `value: "\"AAA?BBB&CC_C\""` inside CloudFormation, which is probably unintentional. IMO it should behave same as `echo` in bash :)

> Try adding that to your serverless.yml and you'll get a value: "\"AAA?BBB&CC_C\"" inside CloudFormation, which is probably unintentional. IMO it should behave same as echo in bash :)

hmm.. can you post some example of env configuration in serverless.yml, that resolves with unwanted quotes (?)

> > Try adding that to your serverless.yml and you'll get a value: ""AAA?BBB&CC_C"" inside CloudFormation, which is probably unintentional. IMO it should behave same as echo in bash :)
> 
> hmm.. can you post some example of env configuration in serverless.yml, that resolves with unwanted quotes (?)

You are correct, my mistake! Must have been something else which caused the extra quotes to be interpreted! Will close this PR 👍

title: Having an event only for prod stage
body:
# This is a Bug Report

## Description

I'm would like to use a schedule event on a function but only on the production stage. I'm trying to do something like that : 

    functions:
        myfunction:
            handler: myfunction.handler
                stage: production
                    events:
                         - schedule: cron(0 15 * * ? *)

Is there a way to do that ? Thanks a lot 

## Additional Data

* ***Serverless Framework Version you're using***: 1.5.1
* ***Operating System***: OS X 10.12
author: chrishiste

comments.body: I believe you could use the variable system to load nothing into events for every stage other than production.
Ok thanks a lot ! I'm gonna check it out

Hello again, I've been trying to use the variable system but even though it seems really powerful I couldn't find a way to do what you said. It seems that there is no way to do an if statement like : 
if ${opt:stage} == 'prod', I could also do it from JS and references it like they show in the doc but then I don't know which stage I'm deploying too. Did you already do something similar ? Sorry, I'm fairly new to Serverless

@chrishiste I don't have time to test it at the moment but it will look something like:

```yaml
custom:
  stage: "${opt:stage, self:provider.stage}"
  prod:
    schedule:
       - schedule: cron(0 15 * * ? *)
  dev:
    schedule:

functions:
    myfunction:
        handler: myfunction.handler
            stage: production
                events: ${self:custom.${self:custom.stage}.schedule}        
```

That way it loads `custom.prod.schedule` when you're on deploying to production and `custom.dev.schedule` when you're deploying to development.

THANKS A LOT! I didn't really understood the variable system until now

If anyone is looking to do something similar that's how I did it : 

```yaml
custom:
  stage: "${opt:stage, self:provider.stage}"
    prod:
      schedule: cron(0 15 * * ? *)
   dev:
      schedule:

functions:
   myFunction:
     handler: myFunction.handler
     events:
       - schedule: ${self:custom.${self:custom.stage}.schedule}
```

Just make sure you pass "--stage" and not "-s"
Nice! Thanks for helping and thanks for posting the solution so that others can use it as well!
Maybe this could be added to the main schedule documentation, I think it is a quite common use case to only have the schedular running for the production lambda.

Could also use `enabled` to turn them on or off for different stages

```
functions:
  fetch:
    handler: handler.fetch
    events:
    - schedule:
        rate: rate(1 minute)
        enabled: ${self:custom.scheduleEnabled.${self:provider.stage}}

custom:
  scheduleEnabled:
    prod: true
    dev: false
    local: false
```

> Could also use `enabled` to turn them on or off for different stages
> 
> ```
> functions:
>   fetch:
>     handler: handler.fetch
>     events:
>     - schedule:
>         rate: rate(1 minute)
>         enabled: ${self:custom.scheduleEnabled.${self:provider.stage}}
> 
> custom:
>   scheduleEnabled:
>     prod: true
>     dev: false
>     local: false
> ```

Is this confirmed to work, with booleans? Because it seems that booleans are not allowed, giving `Trying to populate non string value into a string...` error.

@juanilarregui I have a similar issue when I write `enabled: false` it does deploy but I can see that the CloudWatch event is still enabled in the AWS Console. 

Have you found a way to make it work?
I dont seem to get any issues with the code I posted above. Could you post a copy of what your doing?

> Could also use `enabled` to turn them on or off for different stages
> 
> ```
> functions:
>   fetch:
>     handler: handler.fetch
>     events:
>     - schedule:
>         rate: rate(1 minute)
>         enabled: ${self:custom.scheduleEnabled.${self:provider.stage}}
> 
> custom:
>   scheduleEnabled:
>     prod: true
>     dev: false
>     local: false
> ```

This doesn't disable the schedule, it deploys though.

title: Refactor: Clear "that = this" pattern from codebase
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Acknowledge ALL below remarks -->
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Request may not be processed if it doesn't meet outlined criteria -->

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates  -->
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Plugin enhancements should be proposed at plugin repository, not here -->

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Answer ALL required questions below -->

<!--
Q1: Describe the problem (use case) that needs to be solved
-->

### Use case description

`that = this` Resembles questionable and heavily outdated pattern.

It was used before we had arrow functions, to maintain access to `this` across nested function references, with arrow functions `this` is shared and cases can be referenced directly

<!--
Q2: Propose solution (e.g. provide configuration example)

Note: This is optional, remove this section if you do not wish to propose anything at this point
-->

### Proposed solution

Simply remove `const that = this` and replace all `that` references with `this` (mind eventual non-arrow function expressions which rely on top level `that` if there are any upgrade them to arrow functions)

title: Custom authorizer for websockets connection not passing claims to next function and calling $disconnect rather than $connect
author: mrowles

comments.body: thanks for reporting @mrowles ... I'm guessing you're using Cognito?

@eahefnawy Yep! Which isn't/wasn't supported for Websockets out of the box as of 1.39.1. So I rolled my own custom Cognito one. However, not sure if it matters what the auth is, looks like this might be a problem beyond that.

I've updated, this is actually triggering (as of `serverless@1.40.0`) but still no claims passed over.

I've just realised that it seems as though my client code is actually triggering the `$disconnect` routeKey for some weird reason...I don't even know how, because you're not allowed to specify a customAuthoriser on the `$disconnect` path (which I haven't):

**Lambda Request Context**
```
requestContext: { routeKey: '$disconnect' }
```

> I have even tried separating the `$connect` & `$disconnect` handlers and it keeps sending it to the $disconnect:


We have the same result as you, for some reason a Custom Authoriser trigger Disconnect rather then Connect. We also tried to split connect and disconnect to separate handlers but to no avail, it still trigger disconnect.

**UPDATE:**
It was our fault. When i rewrote our custom authorizer to async await rather than promise().then() it started to work. The fault was probably something like the lambda terminated before the callback(null, policy) had finnished.
Can this get some love please?

@Denjul I have tried everything, including switching to async await - still bloody called disconnect 😅. Are you just doing a `callback(null, claims)` or something else? I can confirm that the lambda is running through it's entirety correctly (with a return statement), but just passing onto `$disconnect`
This was awesome @Denjul! I was missing the policy effect being passed back. Thanks for the assistance :)

Thank you for reporting @jswift 👍 

>I ended up deleting the CloudFormation stack. 

Did you delete the stack directly on AWS management console?
If so, You can't control the service via `serverless deploy` since the S3 bucket for the deployment has been left(Your service was broken). You needed to delete the service via `serverless remove`.

You might want to look for the deployment bucket,  which name would include `-serverlessdeploymentbucket-`. You could deploy again if you remove it once manually.

```
CodeSHA256 (xx) is different from current CodeSHA256 in $LATEST (xx). Please try again with the CodeSHA256 in $LATEST.
```

Same with me, I downgraded to 1.13 and it didn't fix it, but after waiting a while it's working again.

This might have been an AWS issue after all?

Thanks for the feedback everyone 👍 

We saw such a behavior a few months ago. It was also resolved by simply waiting and re-reploying after some time. Seems to be smth. on AWS end.

I'll close this issue for now. Feel free to re-open / continue the discussion if this problems pops up again.

FWIW, we've been seeing this failure a lot more frequently over the past several days.  We're on 1.5 right now and not able to move up to latest quite yet.  As others have said, retrying once or twice takes care of it.

Did anyone actually figure out what the problem generally seems to be when this error occurs?

It's hard to believe that AWS has some batch job that runs once a day that magically fixes all the SHA problems. Maybe they do?
Adding `versionFunctions: false` to the provider property of serverless.yml is a possible workaround.

I just ran into this myself because I we had to workaround permissions issues in the built zip by unzipping, chmodding, and then rezipping.  I created a script to update the SHAs in the json files, the primary guts of which are:

```
# Fix perms in built zip
mkdir package-temp
mkdir deploy-temp
unzip -d package-temp/ .serverless/group-api.zip
rm .serverless/group-api.zip
cp .serverless/* deploy-temp/
chmod o+r package-temp/*
zip -j deploy-temp/group-api.zip package-temp/*

# Update SHA hash in json files
sha=$(openssl dgst -sha256 -binary deploy-temp/group-api.zip | openssl enc -base64)
echo CodeSHA256 is ${sha}
sed -i "s/\"CodeSha256\": \".*\"/\"CodeSha256\": \"${sha}\"/g" deploy-temp/*.json

# Deploy fixed zip/json files
./node_modules/.bin/serverless deploy --package deploy-temp
```
BTW I also experienced this using claudiajs (not serverless framework). So there's something on AWS's end.
I have also been hitting this issue a lot more frequently , but updating the stack does not seem to fix it, versionFunction: false does not allow you to update your lambda functions. Any solutions ?

For me, it happened because I used the same filename in `artifact` for two functions
So I renamed the ZIP files ... and now it works

The issue:
```
functions:
  statusBadge:
    handler: index.handler
    package:
      artifact: ./services/commit-badges/dist/dist.zip
...

functions:
  statusBadge:
    handler: index.handler
    package:
      artifact: ./services/status-badges/dist/dist.zip
```

Solution:
```
functions:
  statusBadge:
    handler: index.handler
    package:
      artifact: ./services/commit-badges/dist/dist_commit_badges.zip
...

functions:
  statusBadge:
    handler: index.handler

I found a solution by updating the permissions in was IAM:

### Debugging:
When running the deploy command add the `--verbose` option, this gave me this:
```
CloudFormation - CREATE_FAILED - AWS::Lambda::Version - XXX
```

### Solution:
In IAM I gave my Policy that is attached to the user that is authenticated with the `aws configure` command full access to Lambda. I would absolutely not advise you to do the same if this is production code, instead, you should find the specific Access setting that is needed, I think it's in `Permissions Management` somewhere.
Now that line has changed to:
```
CloudFormation - CREATE_COMPLETE - AWS::Lambda::Version - XXX
```

Having encountered this with my own local plugin - the issue was that SLS was doing a SHA on the old artifact prior to the build, which would then generate a new artifact with a different SHA when uploaded.

Using the lifecycle hook `package:init` instead of `package:compileFunctions` fixed the issue for me.
